Award.AwardTitle: IV Latin-American Congress on Lie Groups and Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to support participants from the US attending the IV Latin-American Congress on Lie Groups and Geometry in CIMAT, Guanajuato, Mexico, August 27-31, 2012. The study of Lie groups in Geometry has a long history, developed by figures such as Sophus Lie, Felix Klein, Wilhelm Killing, Elie Cartan, Hermann Weyl, etc. In particular, Klein proposed that specifying an appropriate transformation group leaving certain geometric objects invariant, one would then observe various geometries. At the global level, whenever a Lie group acts on a geometric object, such as a Riemannian manifold, this action provides a measure of rigidity and yields a rich algebraic structure in terms of its Representation Theory on tensors, cohomology groups, etc. The scientific focus of the conference is the interaction between Lie Group Theory, Geometry and Topology in the broadest possible sense. Topics to be touched upon in the conference will be: infinite-dimensional Lie algebras and their applications to geometry and topology, infinite dimensional representations as spaces of functions on a manifold, representation theory of Real Semisimple Lie Groups and Integrable Systems, actions of the mapping class group on the representation varieties of surface groups, special holonomy, proper affine actions on Minkowski space, Lie groups and their arithmetic subgroups, tessellations of homogeneous spaces, unipotent dynamics, etc.

The aim of the fourth Latin-American Congress on Lie Groups and Geometry is to disseminate the latest developments in the area to both senior and junior mathematicians. This meeting will bring together researchers from all over Latin-America, USA and Europe, working in diverse areas related by their use of Lie groups in their different facets, namely geometrical, topological, algebraic, etc. It will also raise awareness of the excellent academic work taking place in Latin America and provide a networking opportunity for researchers and students. Graduate students and postdocs will especially benefit from the interaction with the senior mathematicians. Researchers working in developing countries will have the chance to interact with their counterparts from the USA and Europe. https://sites.google.com/site/4liegroupsandgeometry/home

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference was organized as a week-long series of lectures. There were 6 to 7 talks every day. We  had two plenary talks during the morning by the senior participants and  four other invited speakers presented the remaining lectures. The structure and schedule encouraged  informal discussion outside the classrooms.  The conference, and the interactions between students and reserches was very productive and stimulating.

Graduate students from Mexico, Spain, Argentina, USA, etc had the oportunity to listen to lectures by specialist in Geometry and Lie Groups from all over the world. Many of them were able to present their work in the form of a lecture other in more informal settings.


The study of Lie groups in Geometry has a long history. Initially, Sophus Lie wanted to develop a Galois theory for differential equations. Lie thought of a group as a transformation group, in other words, that there had to be some geometric space on which the Lie group had to act. Klein proposed that by specifying an appropriate transformation group that leaves certain objects invariant, one will observe various geometries. This idea eventually led to the notion of a G-structure, where G is a Lie group of local symmetries of a manifold.

Nowadays, Lie groups play a very important role in geometry and theoretical physics. At the global level, whenever a Lie group acts on a geometric object, such as a Riemannian manifold, this action provides a measure of rigidity and yields a rich algebraic structure. On the other hand, there is also Representation Theory, which is the study of the ways a group can act on a vector space, let it be the tangent space of a manifold at a point, a cohomology group, etc.

The scientific focus of the conference is the interaction between Lie Group Theory and Geometry and Topology in the broadest possible sense. It is broad enough to attract significant number of mathematicians from all over the Americas, but also it is specialized enough so that everyone will be interested in every lecture. Some topics to be touched upon in the conference will be: infinite-dimensional Lie algebras and their applications to geometry and topology, infinite dimensional representations as spaces of functions on a manifold, representation theory of Real Semisimple Lie Groups and Integrable Systems, actions of the mapping class group on the representation varieties of surface groups, special holonomy, proper affine actions on Minkowski space, Lie groups and their arithmetic subgroups, tessellations of homogeneous spaces, unipotent dynamics, etc.
